description: From Old French defunct (French défunt), from Latin dēfunctus, past participle of dēfungor (“to finish, discharge”).

adjectives.description: defunct (comparative more defunct, superlative most defunct)

definitionGroups.group: No longer in use or active, nor expected to be again.

entries.meaning: (business) No longer in business or service, nor expected to be again.
(computing) Specifically, of a process: having terminated but not having been reaped (by its parent or an inheritor), and thus still occupying a process slot. See also zombie, zombie process.

examples: […]  he saw Robert Johnston, pannel, come out of the cott-house with the fork in his hand, and pass by Alexander Fall and the deponent; heard the pannell say, he had sticked the dog, and he would stick the whelps too; whereupon the pannell run after the defunct’s son with the fork in his hand,  […]

verbs.description: defunct (third-person singular simple present defuncts, present participle defuncting, simple past and past participle defuncted)
